Question: Why does one only cultivate the homogeneous in the path of seeing?
In the path of cultivation, can one cultivate the homogeneous and heterogeneous?
Answer: Because the location and antidote of the path of seeing are definite, one only cultivates the homogeneous.
The location and antidote of the path of cultivation are indefinite.
Therefore, one can cultivate the homogeneous and heterogeneous.
Furthermore, because the object and antidote of the path of seeing are definite, one only cultivates the homogeneous.
The object and antidote of the path of cultivation are indefinite.
Therefore, one can cultivate the homogeneous and heterogeneous.

Furthermore, in the path of seeing, one first attains the holy nature and first cultivates the characteristics of the holy practices regarding the four noble truths, therefore one only cultivates the homogeneous.
In the path of cultivation, one has already attained the holy nature.
Regarding the four noble truths, one has already cultivated the characteristics of the holy practices.
Therefore, one can cultivate the homogeneous and heterogeneous.
Furthermore, in the path of seeing, one first attains the insight into the truths.
One first attains the direct realization, therefore one only cultivates the homogeneous.
In the path of cultivation, one has already attained the insight into the truths and has already attained the direct realization.
Therefore, one is able to cultivate both similar and dissimilar types.

This is the brief explanation of this matter.
If one cultivates the knowledge of dharmas, does one also cultivate the knowledge of species?
The answer is: one should make four alternatives.
Because the meaning is not definite, there is cultivation of the knowledge of dharmas but not the knowledge of species.
That is to say, when entering the realization of the knowledge of dharmas of suffering, accumulation, cessation, and path,
the arhat who has seen the traces of learning,
when the knowledge of dharmas is present,
Among them, when entering the realization of the knowledge of dharmas of suffering, accumulation, cessation, and path,
that is to say, when the four knowledges of dharmas in the path of seeing,
one only cultivates the knowledge of dharmas and does not cultivate the knowledge of species.
Why is it so?
In the path of seeing, if these merits are cultivated in the present and future,
when the merit of Dharma knowledge is present,
only future Dharma knowledge is cultivated.
When the merit of subsequent knowledge is present,
only future subsequent knowledge is cultivated. Learners who have seen the traces and arhats,
when the knowledge of dharmas that has already been attained is present,
learners refer to the individuals of stream-enterer, once-returner, and non-returner.
Traces refer to the four noble truths.
Because they have already seen the traces of the four truths with uncontaminated wisdom, they are called learners who have seen the traces.
Arhats refer to those liberated by wisdom or those liberated in both ways.
When these learners and non-learners have the knowledge of dharmas that has already been attained present, they only cultivate the knowledge of dharmas.
Because it is habitual cultivation, they do not cultivate subsequent knowledge.
Why is this?
When the knowledge of dharmas that has already been attained is present,
its power is weak and cannot even reach the second moment,
let alone be able to cultivate the other distant future ones.
There is cultivation of subsequent cognition but not of dharma cognition.
This refers to when one enters the realization of the cognition of suffering, origin, and cessation.
A learner who has attained the state of a non-returner and an arhat.
As for when one enters the realization of the cognition of suffering, origin, and cessation,
this refers to when one attains the three subsequent cognitions in the path of seeing.
One only cultivates subsequent cognition and does not cultivate dharma cognition.

When giving rise to the four immeasurables, conventional liberation, mastery, pervading, conventional mindfulness, conventional unobstructed understanding, non-conflict, knowledge of others' minds, ultimate concentration, emptiness of emptiness, wishlessness of wishlessness, signlessness of signlessness, samÄdhi, entering the concentration of cessation, subtle thought of conceptualization,

There are those who do not cultivate both.
Namely, learners who have seen the traces and arhats,
when conventional knowledge that has already been attained is present,

in the minds of all ordinary beings, in defiled minds, in indeterminate minds, in the concentration of non-perception, in the concentration of cessation, in the heaven of non-perception, in the acceptance of the absence of outflows,
Here, when learners who have seen the traces and arhats have conventional knowledge that has already been attained present,
it refers to when learners and those beyond learning have conventional knowledge that has already been attained present.
Their power is weak and they are still unable to cultivate their own future contaminated qualities.
how much less so the various kinds of knowledge of dharmas and inferential knowledge.
When one who has not yet attained conventional knowledge is not cultivating it when it is present,
it refers to the state of learners and post-learners who have not yet attained the wisdom born of hearing and contemplation.
And when entering the concentration of cessation, the mind of subtle and subtle [thought] is present,
one is not able to cultivate knowledge of dharmas and inferential knowledge.
All ordinary beings,
it refers to when ordinary beings have a mind in any state, they are not able to cultivate knowledge of dharmas and inferential knowledge.
Because this is not the dharma cultivated by ordinary beings.
A defiled mind,
it refers to when the defiled minds of noble ones are present,
they are not able to cultivate knowledge of dharmas and inferential knowledge.
Because defiled minds are conducive to retrogression, their nature is heavy and associated with laziness.
They themselves are not cultivating,
how much less so can they cultivate the pure qualities of others.
Only a mind that is conducive to the superior division, whose nature is light and subtle, and associated with vigor, is able to cultivate goodness.
A neutral mind,
That is, when the minds of the noble ones are present as indeterminate,
they are all unable to cultivate Dharma knowledge and inferential knowledge.
Because indeterminate minds are lowly and weak, like rotten seeds.
They themselves are not cultivated,
let alone able to cultivate the pure qualities of others.
Only a firm and superior mind can cultivate merits.
The attainment of non-perception and the attainment of cessation.
That is, when abiding in the attainment of non-perception and abiding in the attainment of cessation,
both are unable to cultivate Dharma knowledge and inferential knowledge.
Only when there is a mind can there be cultivation.
Because in a mindless state one is unable to cultivate.
The heaven of non-perception.
Some say:
When born there, one never arouses a wholesome mind at any time.
Therefore, one is unable to cultivate Dharma knowledge and inferential knowledge.
Some say:
Although one arouses a wholesome mind when born there,
one is unable to cultivate the wholesome dharmas of practice.
Because one only arouses the wholesome dharmas obtained by birth.
One is not even able to cultivate the contaminated [wholesome dharmas] of practice,
let alone able to cultivate Dharma knowledge and inferential knowledge. How could one be able to cultivate them?
At the time of undefiled patience,
it means that in the path of seeing, the eight undefiled patiences cannot cultivate wisdom.
At that time, one only cultivates one's own kind of merits,
not the merits of other kinds.
Why, when one has already attained wholesome dharmas and they are present,
can one not cultivate other future wholesome merits?
The answer is: because their function is inferior,ğŸ”½because they have already been enjoyed,
because they have already been accomplished,
and because they have already given their fruit.
Moreover, because what has already been cultivated and what has already ceased have no power.
Moreover, when the dharmas that have already been attained arise and are present,
what has already been attained and cultivated is now cultivated again.
The two cultivations of past and future only have loss and no increase.
How can one further cultivate the wholesome that has not yet been attained?
It is like a person using the wealth that has already been accumulated.
There is only loss and no increase.
How can it be called further accumulating wealth that has not yet been accumulated?
Moreover, if wholesome dharmas that arise through much effort
can cultivate other future wholesome dharmas,
Because when the wholesome [mind] obtained through preparatory effort is present, it is not necessary to expend much effort.
Therefore, one cannot cultivate future wholesome dharmas.
Moreover, if when the wholesome [mind] obtained through preparatory effort is present,
one can cultivate future wholesome dharmas,
then when the World-Honored One was about to enter nirvana,
he sequentially entered various meditative absorptions and samÄdhis,
he should also have been able to cultivate future merits.
When the World-Honored One first gave rise to the knowledge of destruction,
he had already fully attained the cultivation of all merits.
If he now cultivated them again, he should not have attained them before.
If so, then the merits of the previous stage were not yet complete.
When he first became a Buddha, he should not have been ultimate,
realizing supreme perfect enlightenment.
Do not make this mistake!
Therefore, when the wholesome [mind] obtained through preparatory effort is present,
one definitely cannot cultivate future wholesome dharmas.
The meaning of cultivating the other knowledges is explained in detail in the text.
According to the previous section, one should know its characteristics.
The knowledge of dharmas up to the knowledge of the path,
Among the eight knowledges, how many knowledges does each one take as its object?
Why does this treatise ask this question?
The answer is: in order to refute other schools and reveal the correct principle.
This means that some say:
all objects of cognition do not actually exist.
In order to refute this view and show that objects of cognition actually have their own substance, this treatise is composed.
The answer is: the knowledge of dharmas takes seven knowledges as its object,
excluding the knowledge of subsequent cognition.
The knowledge of subsequent cognition takes seven knowledges as its object,
excluding the knowledge of dharmas.
Why is this so? The knowledge of dharmas takes lower [realms] as its object, while the knowledge of subsequent cognition takes higher [realms] as its object.
Therefore, they do not take each other as objects.
It is like two people living in the same place, one person looking at the ground,
one person looking at the sky.
These two people do not see each other's faces.
The knowledge of others' minds and conventional knowledge both take eight knowledges as their objects.
This is because these two can generally take the mind and mental factors as their objects.
The knowledge of suffering and the knowledge of the origin both take two knowledges as their objects,
namely the knowledge of others' minds and conventional knowledge.
This is because these two can only take defiled classes of mind as their objects.
The knowledge of cessation does not take knowledge as its object because it takes the unconditioned as its object.
The knowledge of the path takes seven knowledges as its object, excluding conventional knowledge.
Because it takes the truth of the path as its object.
The remaining [knowledge] makes a separate question here, saying:
The knowledge of dharmas up to the knowledge of the path,
in the eight knowledges, how many knowledges does each take as its object?
It then answers itself, saying:
The knowledge of dharmas takes four knowledges as its object,
excluding the knowledge of subsequent, suffering, accumulation, and cessation.
The knowledge of subsequent takes four knowledges as its object,
excluding the knowledge of dharmas, suffering, accumulation, and cessation.
The knowledge of others' minds takes seven knowledges as its object,
excluding the knowledge of cessation.
Conventional knowledge takes six knowledges as its object,
excluding the knowledge of cessation and the path.
The knowledge of suffering, accumulation, cessation, and the path take five knowledges as their object,
excluding the knowledge of suffering, accumulation, and cessation.
The knowledge of dharmas up to the knowledge of the path, in mutual comparison, how many conditions are there?
Question: Why does this treatise make this discussion?
Answer: In order to stop other schools and reveal the correct principle.
That is to say, some hold that conditions do not have real substance.
In order to refute this view and to show that the four conditions really have their own substance, this treatise is composed.
The answer is: Dharma cognition is the four conditions for dharma cognition.
And so on, it is explained in detail.
Why is there a difference here from what is said in the Unskillful Chapter of the Aggregates?
Here it is said that dharma cognition is the four conditions for dharma cognition.
In the Unskillful Chapter, it is said that the view of self is either the four, three, two, or one condition for the view of self.
The answer is: As it is said here, it should also be so there.
As it is said there, it should also be so here.
But in order to show the differences in meaning and wording and to cause those who uphold it to give rise to joy,
Furthermore, in order to show two doors, two summaries, two shadows, two ladders, two steps, two lights, and two torches, and to make it known that what is said mutually illuminates each other,
Furthermore, that is the definitive meaning.
This is not the definitive meaning.
That is said without a separate intention.
This is said with a separate intention.
That is said without a separate condition.
This is said to have a separate condition.
That is said to depend on ultimate truth.
This is said to depend on conventional truth.
Moreover, that is said to depend on four kinds of distinctions.ğŸ”½Namely, distinctions in realms.
Distinctions in worlds.ğŸ”½Distinctions in moments.
Distinctions in conditions as the immediately preceding equivalent.
This is only said to depend on one kind of distinction.
Namely, distinctions in conditions as the immediately preceding equivalent.
As for the dharma cognition being the four conditions for dharma cognition,
Namely, cause, condition as the immediately preceding equivalent, object, and dominant.
Among them, cause is like the principle of seeds.
Condition as the immediately preceding equivalent is like the principle of making way.
Object is like the principle of a pillar or staff.
Dominant is like the principle of non-obstruction.
As for dharma cognition being the condition of the same kind for dharma cognition,
Namely, as one cause, which is the similar cause.
As for being the condition as the immediately preceding equivalent,
Dharma cognition, in the present, arises immediately after dharma cognition.
As for being the condition as object,
Dharma cognition arises while taking dharma cognition as its object.
As the dominant condition,
it means that Dharma cognition does not obstruct the arising of Dharma cognition.
As three conditions for inferential cognition, excluding the object condition,
it means that Dharma cognition is three conditions for inferential cognition,
excluding the object condition.
As the causal condition,
it means that Dharma cognition is one cause for inferential cognition,
namely the homogeneous cause.
As the immediately preceding condition,
it means that immediately after Dharma cognition, inferential cognition appears in the present.
As the dominant condition,
it means that Dharma cognition does not obstruct the arising of inferential cognition.
Excluding the object condition,
it means that Dharma cognition and inferential cognition do not mutually take each other as objects.
As four conditions for cognition of others' minds, and so on,
it means that Dharma cognition and the cognition of others' minds in one's own continuum
are causal, immediately preceding,
but not object conditions.
As the object condition for the cognition of others' minds in another's continuum,
it is not a causal or immediately preceding condition.
The rest is as explained above.
As three conditions for conventional cognition, excluding the causal condition,
It means that conditions are like the principle of seeds.
Because the pure and the contaminated are not the principle of seeds.
Dharma cognition and conventional cognition are not conditions.
They are only three conditions.
As conditions for cognition of suffering, origination, and cessation, they are three conditions, excluding the condition as object.
Cognition of suffering and origination takes contaminated [dharmas] as objects.
Because dharma cognition is pure, it is not their object.
Cognition of cessation takes unconditioned dharmas as objects.
Because dharma cognition is conditioned, it is not their object.
As four conditions for cognition of the path, they are as explained before.
Analogy cognition is four conditions for analogy cognition, and so on.
The characteristics should be understood according to dharma cognition.
As four conditions for cognition of others' minds, and so on,
among them, the condition as cause
refers to the same type of cause.
The rest is as explained before.
As four conditions for conventional cognition,
among them, the condition as cause
refers to the causes of the same type and of karmic retribution.
The rest is as explained before.
As four conditions for cognition of suffering and origination, and so on,
It refers to the uncontaminated knowledge of others' minds.
The knowledge of suffering and accumulation are of the same type as the cause.
It is definitely not the object. Because they take contaminated [dharmas] as objects.
If the contaminated knowledge of others' minds
is the object of the knowledge of suffering and accumulation,
it is definitely not the causal condition.
Because the contaminated [dharmas] are not the causal condition for the uncontaminated [dharmas].
It is the three conditions for the knowledge of cessation, excluding the object.
Because it takes the unconditioned [dharmas] as objects.
It is the four conditions for the knowledge of the path and the knowledge of dharmas of the path.
The meaning is as explained above.
The conventional knowledge is the four conditions for the conventional knowledge.
Here, the causal condition
refers to the three causes of the similar, omnipresent, and ripening [dharmas].
The rest is as explained above.
It is the three conditions for the knowledge of suffering and accumulation, excluding the cause.
Because the contaminated [dharmas] are not the causal condition for the uncontaminated [dharmas].
It is the two conditions for the knowledge of cessation and the path, namely the equal and immediately antecedent condition and the dominant condition.
Because they take the uncontaminated [dharmas] as objects.
The rest is as explained above.
With dharma and species cognition, it has three conditions excluding cause.
Because the contaminated does not resemble the uncontaminated as a seed.
With cognition of others' minds, it has four conditions, etc.
That is to say, conventional cognition is the homogeneous cause and immediately antecedent condition for the contaminated cognition of others' minds in one's own continuum.
It is the immediately antecedent condition for the uncontaminated cognition of others' minds in one's own continuum.
Both are not objects.
It is the object for the contaminated cognition of others' minds in another's continuum.
It is not the cause or immediately antecedent condition.
With cognition of suffering, it has three conditions excluding the object for cognition of suffering and cognition of accumulation and cessation, etc.
As explained in detail in the text.
Among them, the reason should be understood according to the previous explanation. Are all bonds bound to the desire realm severed by cognition of the Dharma?
And so on, explained in detail.
Question: Why does this treatise make this discussion?
Answer: In order to make the doubtful attain certainty.
That is to say, cognition of the Dharma can sever the bonds of the form and formless realms.
Cognition of species cannot sever the bonds of the desire realm.
Some give rise to doubt.
Is it that the cognition of dharmas can sever the bonds of the form and formless realms,
and is the cognition of categories also able to sever the bonds of the desire realm?
Just as the cognition of categories cannot sever the bonds of the desire realm,
can the cognition of dharmas also not sever the bonds of the form and formless realms?
In order to cause this doubt to be resolved,
it is shown that the cognition of dharmas definitely can sever the bonds of the form and formless realms,
while the cognition of categories definitely cannot sever the bonds of the desire realm.
Therefore, this treatise is composed.
Question: Why can the cognition of dharmas sever the bonds of the form and formless realms,
but the cognition of categories cannot sever the bonds of the desire realm?
Answer: Because the cognition of dharmas has already severed the bonds of the desire realm,
it can also sever the bonds of the form and formless realms.
Because the cognition of categories has not yet severed the bonds of the form and formless realms,
it cannot sever the bonds of the desire realm.
Furthermore, because the cognition of categories has not yet severed the bonds of the form and formless realms,
the cognition of dharmas severs them.
Because the cognition of dharmas has already severed the bonds of the desire realm, the cognition of categories does not sever them.
Furthermore, if the cognition of the class of dharmas can eliminate the bonds of the desire realm,
how does it eliminate them?
Does it first eliminate the bonds of the form and formless realms,
and then eliminate the bonds of the desire realm?
Or does it first eliminate the bonds of the desire realm,
and then eliminate the bonds of the form and formless realms?
If it first eliminates the bonds of the form and formless realms,
and then eliminates the bonds of the desire realm,
since the coarse bonds of the desire realm have already been eliminated,
what else is there to eliminate?
If it first eliminates the bonds of the desire realm, and then eliminates the bonds of the form and formless realms,
then the cognition of the class of dharmas would be subject to the reproach of others.
One has still not eliminated the bonds of one's own realm,
how can one eliminate the bonds of other realms?
It would be like a king who has not yet subdued the enemies in his own country, yet wants to conquer other countries, and is reproached by others.
Furthermore, all cognition of the class of dharmas definitely takes cognition of the dharmas as its cause,
so cognition of the dharmas can assist in eliminating the bonds of the form and formless realms.
Not all cognition of the dharmas definitely takes cognition of the class of dharmas as its cause.
Therefore the inferential knowledge cannot assist the knowledge of dharmas in eliminating the bonds of the desire realm.
Furthermore, after the knowledge of the class of the path, inferential knowledge often does not appear in the present.
Even if it appears in the present, its power is weak.
It is necessary to be completely free from the bonds of the desire realm.
Only then can the powerful inferential knowledge appear in the present, and therefore it cannot eliminate the bonds of the desire realm.
Furthermore, the knowledge of dharmas must be free from the bonds of the desire realm.
Only then can its function become fierce and sharp.
Because of its fierceness and sharpness, it can eliminate the bonds above.
Inferential knowledge must be free from the bonds of the peak of existence.ğŸ”½Only then can its function become fierce and sharp.
When it is fierce and sharp,
the bonds below have already been eliminated, so what else is there to eliminate?
Furthermore, the knowledge of dharmas is extremely fierce and sharp.
It does not even need to expend effort to eliminate the unwholesome bonds,
let alone the indeterminate bonds, which it cannot eliminate.
It is like an extremely sharp knife that can still cut through iron,
let alone grass and wood, etc.
Inferential knowledge is not extremely fierce and sharp.
It expends much effort to eliminate the indeterminate bonds,
How much less can unskillful bonds be severed?
It is like using a blunt knife to cut grass and wood, etc.
It still requires much effort.
How much less can it cut iron?
Furthermore, the knowledge of dharmas is fully able to sever the eighteen realms, twelve sense bases, and five aggregates.
It is like a strong man whose strength rivals that of a thousand men.
He can sever the higher bonds.
The knowledge of similarity is only able to sever the fourteen realms, ten sense bases, and five aggregates.
Because its power and function are inferior, it does not sever the lower bonds.
Furthermore, the wrong views of the desire realm can take the suffering and accumulation of the three realms as objects and are severed first.
Having already, they further wish to sever those objects.
Therefore, the knowledge of dharmas is able to sever the bonds of the two upper realms.
The wrong views of the form and formless realms
are unable to take the suffering and accumulation of the desire realm as objects.
Therefore, the knowledge of similarity is unable to sever the bonds of the desire realm.
Furthermore, the pervasive bonds of the desire realm that take other realms as objects
are able to take the suffering and accumulation of the form and formless realms as objects and are severed first.
Having already, they further wish to sever those objects.
Therefore, the dharma cognition can eliminate the bonds of the upper two realms.
The universal bonds of the upper realms and other realms are all-pervading.
They do not take the suffering and accumulation of the desire realm as objects.
Therefore, the subsequent cognition cannot eliminate the bonds of the desire realm.
It is like a king who first kills his enemies,
and later also destroys their places of amusement.
Furthermore, the aggregates of the desire realm oppress sentient beings more than a heavy burden.
Having already eliminated them, one often praises their antidotes and cessation.
At that time, one is also able to eliminate the aggregates of the upper realms.
Therefore, the dharma cognition can eliminate the bonds of the upper realms.
The subsequent cognition cannot eliminate the bonds of the desire realm.
However, the dharma cognition can eliminate the bonds of the form and formless realms.
This is the dharma cognition of cessation and path, not the dharma cognition of suffering and accumulation.
Why is it so?
Because it should be so.
That is to say, the practitioner is oppressed by the aggregates of the desire realm more than a heavy burden.
Having already abandoned them, he repays their antidotes
and eliminates evil.
Count and observe again.
When counting and observing again, one is naturally able to sever the bonds of the form and formless realms.
Furthermore, the desire realm is an indeterminate realm, not a realm of cultivation, not a realm of detachment from defilements.
The form and formless realms are determinate realms, realms of cultivation, realms of detachment from defilements, not realms of disgust.
Because dharmas of the indeterminate realm can sever the bonds of the determinate realm.
Furthermore, the desire realm is coarse.
The form and formless realms are subtle.
Because dharmas of the coarse realm that are not disgusted with it cannot sever the bonds of the subtle realm.
Furthermore, the desire realm is inferior.
The form and formless realms are excellent and wonderful. Not being disgusted with
inferior realm dharmas can sever the bonds of excellent and wonderful realm dharmas.
Furthermore, the desire realm is lower.
The form realm is middling.
The formless realm is higher. Not being disgusted with
lower realm dharmas can sever the bonds of middling and higher realm dharmas.
Furthermore, if the cognition of the truth of suffering and its cause can sever the bonds of the form and formless realms,
then one would cultivate disgust in one place and attain liberation in another place.
It is like when the bonds on the hand are severed, one attains liberation of the hand.
If the bonds on the foot are severed, one attains liberation of the foot.ğŸ”½Severing the bonds on the hand does not lead to liberation of the foot.
Severing the bonds on the foot does not lead to liberation of the hand.
Therefore, the knowledge of dharmas that can eliminate the bonds of the form and formless realms
is the knowledge of dharmas of cessation and path, not the knowledge of dharmas of suffering and accumulation.
However, the knowledge of dharmas of cessation and path that can eliminate the bonds of the form and formless realms
only arises in the desire realm, not in the form or formless realms. Why is this?
The mind of skillful means entering and exiting the knowledge of dharmas is only bound to the desire realm.
Those in the upper two realms have already abandoned this mind and will definitely not give rise to it.
Furthermore, the precepts that accompany the knowledge of dharmas
are only produced by the great elements of the desire realm.
Those in the upper two realms have abandoned these great elements and will definitely not give rise to them.
Furthermore, those born in the upper two realms have definitely accomplished what is to be done with the knowledge of dharmas.
The practice has ceased and will not manifest again.
It is like an arhat, whose antidote to eliminating the bonds of the three realms
What has been accomplished will no longer manifest.
Question: If that is so,
why do the arhats give rise to undefiled cognition?
Answer: They wish to contemplate the faults of the aggregates that are to be abandoned,
and to contemplate the benefits of cessation and the path that are to be obtained, therefore
they again give rise to various undefiled cognitions.
Moreover, they give rise to undefiled cognition due to four conditions:
First, in order to abide in the bliss of the present Dharma;
second, in order to play with the merits;
third, in order to observe what has been done before;
fourth, in order to enjoy the wealth of the sages.
The Venerable SubhÅ«ti says:
The disciples of the World-Honored One who are born in the formless realm
do not give rise to the meditative absorptions or the merits produced within the meditative absorptions.
Those born in the form realm are also able to give rise to them.
What does his statement mean?
His statement means that those born in the formless realm
do not give rise to the cognition of dharmas to sever the bonds of the upper realms.

Those born in the form realm, if they have not yet separated from the defilements of the form and formless realms, can also give rise to the cessation and path dharma knowledges and sever the bonds of the form and formless realms.
The judges say:
They should not make this statement.
Why is it so?
If there is this meaning, it should not be definite.
That is to say, being born in the form realm, one can give rise to a part of the dharma knowledge.
One cannot give rise to a part.
As for the part that can be given rise to,
it refers to a part of the cessation and path dharma knowledges.
As for the part that cannot be given rise to,
it refers to the suffering and accumulation dharma knowledges.ğŸ”½Sometimes one can give rise to it,
and sometimes one cannot give rise to it.
As for the one who can give rise to it,
it refers to one who has not yet separated from the defilements of those realms.
As for the one who cannot give rise to it,
it refers to one who has already separated from the defilements of those realms.
Sometimes one can give rise to it, and sometimes one cannot give rise to it.
As for the time when one can give rise to it,
it refers to the time when one gives rise to the path of separating from defilements.
As for the time when one cannot give rise to it,
it refers to the time when one draws in wholesome roots.
Therefore, the previous statement is correct.
Are all the bonds of the desire realm severed by the knowledge of dharmas?
The answer is: Four sentences should be made.
Because the meaning is not definite.
There are bonds of the desire realm that are not severed by the knowledge of dharmas.
Namely, the bonds of the desire realm.
Either severed by patience,
or severed by other knowledge, or not severed.
Among them, those severed by patience are:
The four forbearances of the knowledge of dharmas sever them.
Those severed by other knowledge are:
Severed by conventional knowledge.
Those not severed are:
Because they have already been severed.
Or because the practice of severing them has not yet been undertaken.
There are bonds severed by the knowledge of dharmas that are not of the desire realm.ğŸ”½Namely, the bonds of the form and formless realms severed by the knowledge of dharmas.
The cessation and path of the form and formless realms severed by the knowledge of dharmas.
There are bonds of the desire realm that are also severed by the knowledge of dharmas.ğŸ”½Namely, the bonds of the desire realm severed by the knowledge of dharmas.
The bonds of the desire realm severed by the four knowledges of dharmas.
There are bonds that are neither of the desire realm nor severed by the knowledge of dharmas.
Namely, the bonds of the form and formless realms.
Either eliminated by patience,
or eliminated by other knowledges,
or not eliminated.
Among them, those eliminated by patience
are eliminated by the four types of knowledge of elimination.
Those eliminated by other knowledges
are eliminated by the knowledge of elimination or conventional knowledge.
Those not eliminated
are already eliminated.
Or because the practice of elimination has not yet been initiated.
The bonds bound to the form and formless realms,
are those bonds eliminated by the knowledge of elimination?
Answer: Those bonds eliminated by the knowledge of elimination,
those bonds are bound to the form and formless realms.
Namely, the bonds of the form and formless realms eliminated by cultivation are eliminated by the four types of knowledge of elimination.
There are bonds bound to the form and formless realms that are not eliminated by the knowledge of elimination.
Namely, the bonds of the form and formless realms.
Either eliminated by patience,
or eliminated by other knowledges,
or not eliminated.
Among them, those eliminated by patience
are eliminated by the four types of knowledge of elimination.
Those eliminated by other knowledges
are eliminated by the knowledge of the law,
or eliminated by conventional knowledge.
Or they are not severed.
Because they have already been severed.
Or because one has not yet begun the practice of severing them.
The fetters that are severed by seeing suffering.
Are those fetters severed by the knowledge of suffering?
Answer: The fetters that are severed by seeing suffering.
Those fetters are not severed by the knowledge of suffering.
Or they are severed by acceptance.
Or they are severed by other knowledges or not severed.
Among them, those severed by acceptance are severed by the acceptance of the knowledge of the class of suffering.
Those severed by other knowledges are severed by conventional knowledge.
Those not severed are already severed.
Or because one has not yet begun the practice of severing them.
There is definitely no knowledge of suffering that can sever those fetters.
Because pure knowledge can only sever what is severed by cultivation.
If the fetters are severed by the knowledge of suffering, are those fetters severed by seeing suffering?
Answer: The fetters that are severed by the knowledge of suffering, those fetters are not severed by seeing suffering. They are severed by cultivation and pure knowledge.
Because pure knowledge cannot sever what is severed by seeing.
The fetters abandoned by seeing the truths of origination, cessation, and path.
The abandonment by the knowledges of origination, cessation, and path should be understood analogously to the above.
Only the uninterrupted path can abandon the various fetters.
Because it is said in this treatise that the knowledge of suffering, etc., cannot abandon the fetters abandoned by seeing.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
